title: 103_s2479
content: The "United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994" promotes the construction and operation of US flag cruise vessels in the country. It amends the Act of 1886 to facilitate coastwise transportation of passengers. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 promotes US flag cruise vessels for coastwise passenger transportation. Vessels must be owned by US citizens, meet specific requirements, and have documentation with a coastwise endorsement. An exception is made for cruise vessels under a demise charter lasting at least 18 months to a qualified individual or entity. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 allows cruise vessels under a demise charter of at least 18 months to operate in coastwise trade for up to 6 months after the charter ends, with approval from the Secretary and compliance with specified terms. An exception is granted for cruise vessels not documented under chapter 121 of title 46, United States Code, on the enactment date of the Act. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 allows cruise vessels to operate in coastwise trade for up to 6 months after a demise charter of at least 18 months ends, with approval from the Secretary and compliance with specified terms. An exception is granted for vessels not documented under chapter 121 of title 46, United States Code, on the enactment date of the Act. The authority to operate ceases 18 months after a certificate of documentation with a coastwise endorsement is first issued for the vessel after the Act's enactment date if certain conditions are not met. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 allows cruise vessels to operate in coastwise trade for up to 6 months after a demise charter of at least 18 months ends. The Secretary of Transportation may extend the 18-month period for an additional 6 months for good cause. Limitations on operations include not operating between certain ports served by other cruise vessels and not operating in Hawaii. Penalties, including civil penalties, apply to those operating vessels in violation of the Act. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 allows cruise vessels to operate in coastwise trade for a limited period. Penalties, including civil penalties and vessel seizure, apply to those violating the Act. Additionally, disqualification from coastwise trade is imposed on those failing to meet construction contract requirements for cruise vessels. In the United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994, definitions for terms like coastwise trade, cruise vessel, and related person are provided. SEC. 4. CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS. Section 3309 of title 46, United States Code, is amended to allow vessels meeting specific criteria to comply with certain regulations and receive a certificate of inspection. The criteria include meeting standards for control verification certificates, having a coastwise endorsement issued after 1994, and being authorized for coastwise trade under a specific act. The curr_chunk states that the amendment allows vessels meeting certain criteria to comply with regulations and receive a certificate of inspection. SEC. 5 amends the Shipping Act, 1916 regarding citizenship for vessel operation in passenger transport. SEC. 6 amends the Merchant Marine Act, 1936 by including passenger and cargo. SEC. 7 addresses permits for vessels entering national park units. The Secretary of the Interior has priority rules for vessel operation in National Park System units. First priority is for vessels documented in the US or with rights under the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act. Second priority is for foreign-documented vessels already permitted. Third priority is for other vessels. Permits for foreign-documented vessels can be revoked or not renewed. The Secretary of the Interior can revoke permits for foreign-documented vessels in National Park System units if a US-documented vessel requests permission and there is a limit on permits. However, this restriction does not apply to those with rights under the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act. Those whose permits are revoked have the right of first refusal for a new permit in the same unit. Permit holders whose permits are revoked or not renewed have the right of first refusal for a new permit in the same National Park System unit. The right is limited to the number of permits that were revoked or not renewed.
